NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: The Colony of Connecticut issued its first currency in 1709. By the time of this issuance of these “small change notes” in 1777, the colonies were engrossed in war with Britain, and currency had moved beyond a financial accommodation in an economy lacking specie, and was now an essential aspect to financing the Revolutionary War, where even two pence was more than a convenience. These were authorized by the General Assembly in Hartford, Connecticut’s colonial government at the time, and were intended to be redeemed five years later.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: These notes were printed as part of a sheet containing eight different notes, denominated 1 shilling, 18 pence, 2 shilling 6 pence, 4 shillings, 5 shillings, 6 shillings, 10 shillings and 20 shillings, of which this is the 6 shilling example. As only 12,000 sheets were printed, only 12,000 examples of this note were printed. Printed by James Adams, previously employed by Ben Franklin in Franklin’s printing operation in Philadelphia, the paper used, which can be seen to contain mica flakes and blue silk fibers, is the same paper used for the later currency issues by the Continental Congress.

NoteInfo.OverrideTitle: 1776 1 Spanish Milled Dollar Georgia Colonia Note
NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: Unsurprisingly, the events of 1776 precipitated several currency issues, and Georgia’s extremely colorful notes are prime examples. Interestingly, the transition from the use of the pence/shilling/pound currency convention to a dollar standard was made in the second 1776 issue, which included colorful seals [blue, maroon, orange, and green seals] with spirited Latin mottoes included in the seals. This example, denominated in the workhorse Spanish Milled Dollar, displays a blue seal containing the motto “SUSTINE RECTUM,” or “Support what is right.”

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: Massachusetts was the first of the American colonies to issue paper currency, doing so with an issue approved on December 10th, 1690, which proceeds were to assist in paying for a military action to be taken against Canada. Almost a century later, paper currency was a familiar sight in the colonies, and some of the designs had begun to employ artistry and symbolism in their devices. The design of this note, square and with a codfish, already an important New England food staple, was part of a series initially engraved by Nathaniel, Hurd but apparently completed by Paul Revere for issue in 1776. In 1778, the plates were modified by Revere in order to issue the 1778 versions, a four-shilling example of which is seen here.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: Colonial Maryland was the first of the colonies to “throw off” the British monetary convention of pence/shilling /pound, recognizing as a matter of practicality the prevalence of Spanish pieces of eight as the specie in use. As such, on January 1, 1767, the first governmental currency denominated in dollars in the world appeared. Ironically, they were payable in London, in bills receivable at a rate of convertibility of four shillings and six pence per dollar. This note, denominated as 6 dollars, is stipulated as equivalent to 27 shillings and is payable in bills receivable in London, or “Gold and Silver.”

NoteInfo.OverrideTitle: 1771 Uncut Sheet of North Carolina Colonial Notes
NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: This “mini-sheet‘ of three notes provides the viewer an idea of how the plates of colonial notes were arrayed and printed. Larger format, higher denominated notes, they were printed from engraved plates, and refer to an oddment – “Proclamation Money.” This term derived from the proclamation issued by Queen Anne on June 18th of 1704, stipulating that the colonies had to utilize pounds, shillings, and pence for accounting purposes, despite the accepted fact that a variety of other countries’ currencies, primarily in specie form were in active use in all the American colonies. As with most efforts to legislate preference, not a successful practice. Artistic vignettes at lower left varied by denomination; the bear on the one pound note is notable for its incorporation of Ursa Minor.

NoteInfo.OverrideTitle: 1775 10 Spanish Milled Dollar New York Colonial Note
NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: Colonial New York Ten Spanish Milled Dollars September 2nd, 1775 The resolution authorizing this issue of $112,500 in currency stipulated that half of it would be repaid on March 1st, 1776, and the remainder March 1st, 1777. Unsurprisingly, this did not occur, the dues dates being later extended by a year. This issue discontinued the dire warnings against counterfeiting printed on previous issues – “Tis Death to Counterfeit” - and was first issued with three signatories, later reduced to two by a resolution of the Provincial Congress of New York, on December 16th, 1776.

NoteInfo.OverrideTitle: 1776 2 Shilling 8 Pence New York Colonial Note
NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: Printed by Samuel Loudon, these notes carry smaller emblems and mottoes on the reverse than the preceding issues of September 2nd, 1775. This denomination’s motto reads “HIS ORNARI AUT MORI,” which translated from the Latin, states “To be decorated with these or die.”

The earliest colonists in Manhattan dug primitive, shallow wells to access water for drinking and other needs. In 1677, at around the time of the departure of the Dutch, a public well was dug in the Bowling green area. As the population grew, this became impractical and insufficient, and in 1776, a larger scale plan, including a reservoir, was created, utilizing a system of interconnected hollowed out logs to distribute the water around lower Manhattan. This work was financed by four series of notes, August 22nd, 1774, August 2nd 1775, January 6th, 1776, and March 5th, 1776. This is the first currency issued by a city in the Americas. This note, part of the third series, is signed by Andrew Gautier, famed for his role in building St. Paul’s Chapel. The backs of all these issues display engraved depictions of hydraulic machinery.

NoteInfo.OverrideTitle: 1799 $27 State of New Hampshire Pay Warrant
NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: Payable to “Theophilus Dame, Esq. or bearer”, and signed by then governor John Taylor Gilman [served 1794-1805; 1813 – 1816]. Dame was a Colonel in New Hampshire’s Revolutionary militia. The bearer nature of this instrument and the lack of specie to allow its conversion would have made it a circulating instrument for some time until its eventual payment, signified by the dual cancellation holes. Printed on the back of paper apparently originally used for another document, “recycled” during war time.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: Because of defective spacing between notes discovered during the first printing, the higher denominations in this issue, the 3 and 6 pound denominations, were made in two printings. The clear margins around this note confirm that it is from the second. With uncharacteristically colorful inks - bright red and blue – and five busy bees marching on the back’s right border.

The March 25th, 1776 issue was the result of long contention with the Crown over the legal tender aspects of the notes, and while ultimately approved February 20th of 1776 [albeit with certain additional requirements], the Revolutionary War would break out before the notes reached circulation, and England’s stipulations would be ignored. This, the 1 shilling, was the lowest of the ten denominations issued, and was printed in red and black, bearing Plate letter “B.”

These notes were printed as part of a sheet containing eight different notes, denominated 1 shilling, 18 pence, 2 shilling 6 pence, 4 shillings, 5 shillings, 6 shillings, 10 shillings and 20 shillings, of which this is the 10 shilling example. As only 12,000 sheets were printed, only 12,000 examples of this note were printed. Printed by James Adams, previously employed by Ben Franklin in Franklin’s printing operation in Philadelphia, the paper used, which can be seen to contain mica flakes and blue silk fibers, is the same paper used for the later currency issues by the Continental Congress.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: The legal tender provisos which attached to these notes by the Acts of the General Assembly which passed them were controversial, as they were enforceable by the courts without jury trial. In an early test [Trevett vs. Weeden], the law was declared invalid, establishing trial by jury as a basic right of the new country’s citizens. After the legal tender proviso was finally repealed in 1789, these notes had lost significant purchasing power; over 90% of the notes were subsequently burned.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: This late issue was printed in only two comparatively large denominations, $20 and $30, and as the face of this, the twenty, indicates, their British pound equivalents were also included on the bottom border – in this case, 32 pounds, 10 shillings. The seal at lower right displays a bird taking flight from a cage, with the Latin motto circling it - “IBI PATRIA UBI LIBERTAS,” or “Here in our country is where freedom is.”

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: These 1780 Virginia notes, issued after the creation of the Continental Congress, share the border designs and emblems used on the January 14th, 1779 issue of Continental Currency. An issue which was designed to assist in refinancing the significantly inflated previous issues by the Congress and intended to remain in circulation until a December 31st, 1786 maturity, these notes bore an inducement - interest at 5%, with the calculations for the interest boxed at lower left. On the back, this denomination’s emblem displays the Latin “SIC FLORET RESPUBLICA” [Thus let the Nation Flourish] surrounding sheltered beehives.

Beginning in April of 1731, Benjamin Franklin began printing the currency for the colony of Pennsylvania; he would continue this until 1848, when he sold the business to David Hall with the agreement that the notes would continue to bear the legend “Printed by Franklin and Hall” until Franklin had been paid. The June 15th, 1767 issues bore a new legend, “Printed by [David] Hall & [William] Sellers.” This note is printed from Plate B – signified among other things by the backwards “S” on the right hand column.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: From the third of fourteen different emissions of currency by the Continental Congress, and the only emission which included these odd denominations [$1/6, $1/3, $1/2, and $2/3]. Of the total authorization of 4 million dollars, 1 million was expressly legislated as for notes of under $1 in denomination, speaking to the lack of specie available. When eventually redeemed for a penny on the dollar beginning in 1790, this note’s value would have been reduced to a third of a penny. Feautured on the face of this note is a sun shining on a sundial emblem, bearing the Latin “FUGIO,” or “Time Flies,” and in English, “Mind Your Business.” The reverse of these Continental fractionals share a thirteen interlocking ring device which was designed by Benjamin Franklin. Each ring is labelled with the name of each of the founding thirteen colonies, and they encircle a central element whose ring text reads “American Congress” around the motto “We Are One.”

Much of the currency issued by the colonies and all of the currency issued by the Continental Congress bears visible symbolism, and nowhere is this more striking than in the seals, containing Latin mottoes and visual devices echoing the point. In this example, we see the Latin “SI RECTE FACIES” surrounding a wreath on a pedestal; the Latin translates to: “If you act righteously you will be honored after death.” The note’s reverse has two seals – at left the image of a gale blown from the heavens is encircled by “VI CONCITAE,” or “Driven by Force,” and at right, the sun shines over a calm sea, encircled by “CESSANTE VENTO CONQUIECEMUS,” or “When the Storm Dies Down We Will Rest.”

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: From the third of fourteen different emissions of currency by the Continental Congress, and the only emission which included these odd denominations [$1/6, $1/3, $1/2, and $2/3]. Of the total authorization of 4 million dollars, 1 million was expressly legislated as for notes of under $1 in denomination, speaking to the lack of specie available. When eventually redeemed for a penny on the dollar beginning in 1790, this note’s value would have been reduced to a third of a penny. Feautured on the face of this note is a sun shining on a sundial emblem, bearing the Latin “FUGIO,” or “Time Flies,” and in English, “Mind Your Business.” The reverse of these Continental fractionals share a thirteen interlocking ring device which was designed by Benjamin Franklin. Each ring is labelled with the name of each of the founding thirteen colonies, and they encircle a central element whose ring text reads “American Congress” around the motto “We Are One.”

While the Federal government has never issued three dollar currency, the denomination was once quite common, seeing issuance by the Colonies, by the Continental Congress, by the banks, states, municipalities and merchants whose paper currency circulated after the Revolutionary War up until the Civil War. The Latin “EXITUS IN DUBIO EST” translates to “The Outcome is in Doubt,” with an allegorical eagle and heron in battle pictured.

By the time of this issue, the United States had formally declared independence, and British forces had already begun massing on Staten Island, preparing for the coming battle of Brooklyn. The Latin motto in the device at left, “MAJORA MINORIBUS CONSONANT” or “the Large Colonies and the Small Colonies are in Harmony,” circles a thirteen stringed harp.

The last and largest issue of the Continental Congress, all dated January 14th, 1779, but authorized by seven different resolutions dated through November 29. 1779, totaled $95,051,695. The plates continued to utilize familiar designs and themes, but new border cuts, containing the modified “United States of North America were incorporated into the plates, and the notes were printed in two colors, red and black. This twenty continues to feature the “VI CONCITATAE” motto [“Driven by Force”].

One of the earliest issues the Continental Congress took up, on July 4th, 1776, was the need for a national seal. No less a trio than John Adams, Benjamin Franklin, and Thomas Jefferson were appointed to this task, and after six years and three committees, a seal was adopted on June 20th, 1782. The modern version of that seal can be seen on the reverse of our one dollar bill, but the design borrows heavily from the device seen on this bill. A thirteen layered pyramid – unfinished – representing the 13 colonies represents a clear symbol of strength, but the viewer might well interpret its unfinished nature as asking the natural question of what the future might bring and an allusion to manifest destiny.

NoteInfo.OverrideTitle: $1 State Bank at New Brunswick Note

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance

NoteInfo.OverrideTitle: 1865 $2 Bank of New-England at Goodspeed's Landing Note

NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: Once the Confederacy broke with the Union, there were numerous governmental activities it need to take over, its finances, including the printing of money, being one of them. It engaged the New Orleans office of the American Banknote Company to print the first four Montgomery issues, but it was rapidly acknowledged that the new country could not do business with a “northern firm” headquartered in New York. The New Orleans office was renamed “Southern Banknote Company,” the tradestyle seen on this early and beautifully designed note. The financial strains on the Confederacy were immediate. The wording on this note, “Six months after a ratification of a treaty of peace between the Confederate States and the United States” suggests that payment of the obligation could only be made once the war was over, half a year afterwards, in fact. The language in the top border, “Fundable in Eight Percent Stock or Bonds of [the] Confederate States of America” suggests that if and when negotiated, note holders would get paper, not specie.

Alternatives to Southern Bank Note/American Bank Note, while perhaps not of equal quality, did exist. One such firm was Leggett, Keatinge & Ball, which later became Keating & Ball. This example, dated September 2nd, 1861 but produced in early 1862 in Richmond, displays Secretary of State Robert Mercer Taliafierro Hunter at left, and at right the Treasurer of the Confederacy, Christopher Gustavus Memminger. The central allegory is of “Hope.” The Union blockade had already become a significant deterrent to trade with the South, and the supply of high quality bank-note paper was deeply affected. These notes show up on a variety of different papers.

Befitting the heavily agricultural interests of the Confederacy, much of it cotton exported to England, this note’s center vignette is of a sailor resting by bales of cotton, with Justice holding her scales at right. Treasurer Christopher Memminger is at lower left. Records indicate 1,002,478 of these were printed, a large volume by the standards and technology of the day, and the overall quality of the impression of these fives suggests this.

While the Confederacy has issued interest bearing notes in high denominations, this was the first hundred dollar issue to be emitted in large quantities and which paid interest. The interest paid was 7.3% per annum, exactly two times that paid [3.65%, or one basis point per day] on the first issues by the Confederacy. As the stamps on the reverse indicate, many bearers kept up with the anniversary payments, despite the fact that the notes had suffered severe devaluation by the latter stages of the war.

Jefferson Davis, featured on four $50 issues of the Confederacy, of which this is the second, is well known as the President [1861-1865] of the Confederacy. He is less known as a graduate of West Point, a second lieutenant in [future U.S. President] Zachary Taylor’s command in Prairie du Chien, Wisconsin Territory, the husband, over Taylor’s objections, of his daughter, Sarah Knox Taylor, and a widower three months later after both contracted malaria in Louisiana. A slaveholder, in 1840 he became politically active, then serving in the Mexican American War, as Secretary of War, and upon the secession of Mississippi, returned to the South and was ultimately chosen as President. Interestingly, this is the first confederate note issued with a printed back, in this case an elegant and intricate design. These notes were printed by Keatinge & Ball, who by May, 1862 had moved from Richmond, Virginia to Columbia, South Carolina.

The vignette at the center of this issue illustrates the state capitol building in Nashville, Tennessee, and the portrait of Alexander Hamilton Stephens, Vice President of the Confederacy, is at lower left. Ironically, Stephens, a slaveholder, served with Abraham Lincoln in Congress, and remained a longtime friend, including meeting at one point during the Civil War to discuss a treaty of peace. An extensive issue, with 4,429,600 issued and printed.

The Confederacy authorized the seventh [and last] series of currency to total $200,000,000. Over $400,000,000 was actually issued. Included in the set was a note with the second largest denomination issued by the Confederacy - $500 - featuring the portrait of General Thomas Jonathan Jackson. Jackson was known as “Stonewall Jackson” for his brigade’s performance at the First Battle of Bull Run on July 21st, 1861. His death from a bullet shot by one of his own soldiers at the Battle of Chancellorsville in May of 1863 was a significant military and morale blow to the South.

From the last issue by the confederacy before their surrender at Appamattox. By the time these notes were issued, it was considered too expensive to print the backs. As a result, the ones and the twos were printed on the face only. Featured at right is the portrait of Judah P. Benjamin, born in St. Croix, Danish West Indies, and after emigration to the United States with his parents, became the first Jewish United States Senator. After the secession of the southern states, he returned to Louisiana, was first appointed Attorney General by Jefferson Davis, then Secretary of War, and then Secretary of State. After the end of the Civil War, he moved to England, became a successful barrister, and died in Paris in 1884.

During the brief period of 1836-45, Texas issued notes under the flag of Mexico, as a republic, as a part of the United States, and as a part of the Confederacy. This note, from 1837, bears the distinctive signature of Sam Houston, President of Texas at the time.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: The War of 1812-1815 brought significant financial pressure on a young country. To meet these demands, the United States Treasury issued small quantities of financial instruments, some of which bore interest, and circulated to a limited extent. This example, from the March 25, 1815 issue, is signed by only 2 of the 3 necessary authorities and as such never technically became legal for circulation.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: The War of 1812-1815 brought significant financial pressure on a young country. To meet these demands, the United States Treasury issued small quantities of financial instruments, some of which bore interest, and circulated to a limited extent. This example, from the March 25, 1815 issue, in the amount of $5, has none of the necessary signatories for issuance.

This note was part of the first federal government issue of US currency to publicly circulate, released in the early part of the Civil War. It was not readily accepted by the American public, who were accustomed to using silver and gold. The color of the back gave the note its nickname, the “greenback.” Printed by outside contractor American Bank Note Company, before the creation of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, these notes are unique in their lack of a Treasury Seal and the names or signatures of the Secretary and Register of the Treasury.

This is an example of one of the first notes issued in significant quantities by the federal government. It bears the engraved portrait of then Secretary of the Treasury and printed signature of Francis Spinner, the second Treasurer of the United States during Abraham Lincoln’s administration and features the engraved portrait of Alexander Hamilton at lower right. It was printed by the National Bank Note Company and was part of the first series of notes issued for general distribution in the United States.

This note features minor design changes, but enhanced seals and complicated engraving on the back that was not merely an artistic endeavor, but served as anti-counterfeiting measures. This basic design type, while modified from series to series, would serve as a $1 denominated workhorse for over 50 years, until 1923. This is the next design type issued in the Legal Tender $1 denomination, which is renowned for its brilliant coloration. It also bears the signature of Francis Spinner, who continued in the office of Treasurer of the United States after Abraham Lincoln’s passing, serving under Presidents Johnson and Grant. The fronts of notes in this issue were printed by the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, while the reverses were contracted to the Columbian Bank Note Company.

This note features minor design changes, but enhanced seals and complicated engraving on the back that was not merely an artistic endeavor, but served as anti-counterfeiting measures. This basic design type, while modified from series to series, would serve as a $1 denominated workhorse for over 50 years, until 1923.

From the last series of large size legal tender notes, this issue shares many design and stylistic features with our current dollar bills. This was the last of the large size United States Notes, replaced in the Coolidge administration by the dimensions of the currency we use today.

Our first federal “$2 bill” bears the engraved portrait in profile of Alexander Hamilton. As the green design element to the immediate right of the portrait suggests, a $3 bill in this series was contemplated, but never issued. The complicated design elements at the lower right were early efforts at anti-counterfeiting devices.

This “rainbow” note features the portrait of President Thomas Jefferson we associate with $2 bills, engraved by outstanding engraver James Smillie. The central vignette of the Capitol reflected the building as it looked just after the 1868 completion of the extensions.

This “rainbow” note features the portrait of President Thomas Jefferson we associate with $2 bills, engraved by outstanding engraver James Smillie. The central vignette of the Capitol reflected the building as it looked just after the 1868 completion of the extensions.

Similar in design elements to the first demand notes, but with seals and printed Treasury officials Lucius Chittenden’s and Francis Spinner’s signatures added, this note features a vignette of “Freedom” at left. This statue, designed by Thomas Crawford, has graced the top of the US Capitol building since installation in 1863.

This note, featuring a familiar portrait of President Andrew Jackson at left, is nicknamed the “woodchopper” because of its central vignette of a pioneer family, in which the central male figure is shown holding an axe. It features intricate engraved scrollwork on the reverse, and the unusual artistry made the notes recognizable as uniquely American expressions of our national identity.

Similar in design elements to the $10 denomination of the 1861 demand notes, but with seals and printed Treasury officials Lucius Chittenden’s and Francis Spinner’s signatures added, this features the vignette of an [at the time] sitting US President, Abraham Lincoln. An intricate note with quite a bit of color, its iconography includes the top center vignette of an eagle and allegorical female representation of Art at the right.

While intended to feature famed US Congressman, Senator and Secretary of State Daniel Webster at lower left, and the presentation of Pocahontas to the English court of King James I in 1616, notes of this design came to be dubbed “jackass notes” because the eagle vignette at the bottom center of the face bears remarkable similarity to the head of a donkey when viewed upside down.

This piece of currency, issued at the time that the United States was on the threshold of the centennial of the Lewis and Clark expedition, celebrates the American West with the portraits of the explorers and the famously iconic vignette of a mature American bison, the largest extant land animal in the western hemisphere. The engraving on the reverse is of Columbia holding, and surrounded by, grain, signifying American abundance.

This piece of currency, issued at the time that the United States was on the threshold of the centennial of the Lewis and Clark expedition, celebrates the American West with the portraits of the explorers and the famously iconic vignette of a mature American bison, the largest extant land animal in the western hemisphere. The engraving on the reverse is of Columbia holding, and surrounded by, grain, signifying American abundance.

Relatively short-lived as a design type, this was the last large size $10 note issued before the introduction of small size currency. It was also the last $10 United States Note. However, President Jackson’s familiar portrait would survive on the nation’s currency by virtue of its move to the small size $20 bills introduced in 1928. The round design elements at the left and right of the back of the note suggest $10 gambling tokens, giving rise to this note’s nickname — the “poker chip note.”

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: This note features a vignette of Liberty holding a sword and a shield, and it bears the printed signatures of Lucius Chittenden and Francis Spinner, Register of the Treasury and Treasurer of the United States. The title Register of the Treasury last appeared on notes dated 1929, and is today replaced by “Secretary of the Treasury.” Note the intricate engraving and use of color on the back.

The face of this note features the portrait in profile of Alexander Hamilton, first US Secretary of the Treasury, as well as a vignette of Victory, war-like with her shield. The entire back of this note is covered in very intricate detail as an anti-counterfeiting measure. Notice the double “X’s” at left, intended as a secondary way to convey the denomination.

A note whose basic design remained unchanged into the 1920s, the reverse of this note is more intricate than the face. It features both Roman and Latin numerals, as well as a statement warning that counterfeiting the note “is a Felony, and is punishable by Five Thousand [$5,000] Dollars FINE or Fifteen [15] years imprisonment at HARD LABOR or both.”

In its era of circulation, the $50 bill was a considerable amount of money [arguably, over $1,000 in today’s dollars]. As such, while they circulated, they were needed in smaller numbers, and are rare today. The vignette of statesman, diplomat, printer, Declaration of Independence signer and scientist Benjamin Franklin is from a portrait painted by Joseph Siffred Duplessis during Franklin’s time in France, engraved by Charles Burt. The image at the right is an allegorical Liberty dressed in the garb of Columbia.

This is the 1880 version of the previous note and has been “modernized” by the removal of the intricate double “L” symbolism for 50 and the movement of the seal to the right. While bearing a “Series of 1880” legend, signers Judson Lyons and Ellis Roberts overlapped in office from April of 1898 to June of 1905, suggesting a turn-of-the-century issue timeframe.

A high denomination note issued at the turn of the century, this represented in excess of $2,500 in current dollars. Unsurprisingly, few have survived, and less than 50 of this signature combination are presently known. It features a classic portrait of President Abraham Lincoln at the left, and an allegorical representation of Architecture at the right.

This note features a vignette of Liberty holding a sword and a shield, and it bears the printed signatures of Lucius Chittenden and Francis Spinner, Register of the Treasury and Treasurer of the United States. The title Register of the Treasury last appeared on notes dated 1929, and is today replaced by “Secretary of the Treasury.” Note the intricate engraving and use of color on the back.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: Similar in design elements to the first demand notes, but with seals and printed Treasury officials Lucius Chittenden’s and Francis Spinner’s signatures added, this features a vignette of “Freedom” at left. This statue, designed by Thomas Crawford, has graced the top of the U.S. Capitol building since installation in 1863.

This variety of this note reflects the removal of the small “starburst” in the lower border and the shift of the Treasury seal’s position, one of many small changes made in our early currency, many intended to foil counterfeiters.

An extremely interesting combination of currency and an interest bearing instrument, known as a Compound Interest Treasury Note, these issues are testimony to the precarious state of the federal finances as the Civil War moved into its latter stages. Dated comparatively late in the war, August 15, 1864, the note promises payment of interest at 6% at the maturity of the note, three years to the day after issue. The payment of the interest only at maturity served as inducement to the holder to hold the note, rather than converting it, easing pressure on the Treasury. The back of this note includes a payment schedule for the interest, compounded biannually. Issued in denominations of $10, $20, $50, $100, $500 and $1,000, all are rare. The two highest denominations are unknown.

A later and longer-term effort to blend circulating currency with interest as an inducement to keep the instrument out in circulation, these notes were issued in a different size format from other issues of the day and bore interest at 4% per year. As enacted on February 26, 1879, the interest was intended to accrue with no time limit, but this feature was revoked by Act of Congress in 1907, capping the accrued interest at $11.30 and the redemption value at $21.30. The reverse bears a quite terse interest schedule, indicating, among other things, that the note accrues interest at the rate of one cent per nine days.

The abundant supplies of silver being mined in the 1880s, the convenience of paper currency over coin, and the continuing political distaste for “unsecured” currency led to the introduction of Silver Certificates in 1878. This example, from the first series of $1 silver certificates issued in 1886 is notable because it features Martha Washington, who is the only “real,” i.e., non-allegorical, female featured on federal paper currency. Because it was backed by hard currency, the note’s reverse stipulates that it could be used in payment of all obligations, including all duties, something many of its peers could not.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: This note is one of the three denominations issued from the Educational Series, widely considered the epitome of US currency design. Designed by Will Low and engraved by Charles Schlect, the central vignette depicts “History Instructing Youth,” and includes the [at the time] recently completed Washington Monument and a large book open to the preamble of a fully legible Constitution of the United States. Wreathed around the left upper and right borders are the names of 23 historically significant Americans. Portraits of Martha and George Washington dominate the reverse.

This note is one of the three denominations issued from the Educational Series, widely considered the epitome of US currency design. Designed by Will Low and engraved by Charles Schlect, the central vignette depicts “History Instructing Youth,” and includes the [at the time] recently completed Washington Monument and a large book open to the preamble of a fully legible Constitution of the United States. Wreathed around the left upper and right borders are the names of 23 historically significant Americans. Portraits of Martha and George Washington dominate the reverse.

From the fourth issue of Silver Certificates and featuring an imposing vignette of our national symbol, clutching flag and olive branches in front of the Capitol, this is the famous “Black Eagle” note. The less prominent vignettes feature the portraits of Abraham Lincoln and Ulysses S. Grant. This note remained in use for an extended period of time – 11 different Treasury signature combinations from 1899 to its 1923 replacement, spanning five presidencies. This would have been what most Americans would have considered the $1 bill during that time.

This note was issued from 1923-1928 and while eventually made obsolete by the country’s long-debated conversion to small size currency begun in 1928, it continued to circulate well into the Great Depression. Its comparatively modern format, employing the traditional and familiar Gilbert Stuart portrait of President Washington, survives to this day in its similarity to our current singles, although its open format, “cogwheel” reverse has long disappeared.

While issued well after the close of the Civil War, many heroes were prominently remembered on the nation’s currency. General Winfield Scott, seen here in a later portrait and famed for four decades of military service and particularly his role at Gettysburg, also ran for President in 1880, but was defeated by the ill-fated James A. Garfield. The denomination and the note’s convertibility into silver are both prominently and elaborately included in a detailed back, containing several anti-counterfeiting design elements.

The face of this note features a portrait of William Windom, Secretary of the Treasury for the scant six months under James A. Garfield and again in the Harrison administration from 1889 to his death, in office, in early 1891. Similarly shaped, but intricate and internally differentiated “counters,” or vignettes containing a note’s denomination, dominate the bank and made counterfeiting an increased challenge.

The $2 denomination in the famed and popular Educational Series features an allegory of “Science presenting Steam and Electricity to Commerce and Manufacturing.” The original artwork was the product of collaboration by Edwin Blashfield and Thomas Morris, and the engraving by famed G.F.C. Smillie and Charles Schlect. The focus on the importance of invention and innovation in industrial America was personified by the back’s portraits of Robert Fulton [credited with creating the first commercially successful steamboat] and Samuel Morse [inventor of the telegraph and Morse code].

Featuring allegorical representation of Mechanics and Agriculture, flanking George Washington, this note was issued in large quantities at a time when $2 bills were popularly and extensively used, and quite commonly encountered in commerce.

This is the first silver certificate issued in the $5 denomination and features the unusual but strikingly engraved device on its reverse of five individual silver dollars, one displaying the obverse and dated 1886, and the remaining four displaying Philadelphia mint reverses. Aside from the National Gold Bank Notes, and the 1863 $20 gold certificate, the only federal note depicting coinage.

This is the first silver certificate issued in the $5 denomination and features the unusual but strikingly engraved device on its reverse of five individual silver dollars, one displaying the obverse and dated 1886, and the remaining four displaying Philadelphia mint reverses. Aside from the National Gold Bank Notes, and the 1863 $20 gold certificate, the only federal note depicting coinage.

Depicting an allegory of “Electricity Illuminating the World,” a vignette engraved by G.F.C. Smillie from a painting by Walter Shirlaw, this note is the highest denomination in the Educational Series. The artful employment of a bare-breasted woman in the design generated controversy and was considered risqué by some elements. The Lorenzo Hatch engraved portraits on the back of the note are of President and General Ulysses S. Grant and General Philip Henry Sheridan, closely associated heroes of the Civil War.

This is one of the few bank notes in any series of US currency that depicts an individual who was not a government official, and the only one that depicts a Native American. It features Chief Running Antelope, one of four chiefs of the Oncpapa tribe of Sioux Indians who acted as advisers to Sitting Bull during the Plains Wars. Ironically, while a Sioux, the Sioux ceremonial head dress was judged difficult to properly fit into the note’s design, resulting in the use of a Pawnee head dress.

This is one of the few bank notes in any series of US currency that depicts an individual who was not a government official, and the only one that depicts a Native American. It features Chief Running Antelope, one of four chiefs of the Oncpapa tribe of Sioux Indians who acted as advisers to Sitting Bull during the Plains Wars. Ironically, while a Sioux, the Sioux ceremonial head dress was judged difficult to properly fit into the note’s design, resulting in the use of a Pawnee head dress.

While we now associate the portrait of President Abraham Lincoln with the $5 bill, it was not always so. This portrait, engraved from the famous Matthew Brady photograph of February 9, 1864, was first used on this denomination of the Federal Reserve Notes of 1913. This slightly later issue has come to be referred to as the “Porthole Note” because of the round window-like frame ringing the portrait. While small size notes began replacing large size currency in 1928, the first small fives bore a 1934 date, well after the onset of the Great Depression.

This early $10 Silver Certificate features the portrait of Robert Morris, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, the Articles of Confederation and the Constitution. As Superintendent of Finance [1781 to 1784], successfully managing the nation’s shaky post-Revolutionary economy, he was arguably the second most important man in the country. As these notes were part of the first issue of notes backed by silver coin, the reverse has the word “silver” spelled out prominently, and the choice of black ink is unique to the early issue in this series.

This note features the face of Thomas Hendricks – Congressman, Senator, Indiana Governor and Vice President in the Cleveland administration, who died in that office after a very short term [March 4, 1885 to November 25 of the same year]. At the time of his death, both the Speaker of the House and Senate President positions were then vacant, leaving no one to replace him, leading to the law passed the following year which placed cabinet members in the line of succession. Issued shortly after his death, the shape of the portrait and his untimely death led to the note’s being referred to as the “Tombstone Note.” The reverse of the note features the skilled engraving work of the time, and a return [from the previous issue’s black reverse] to traditional green ink.

Representing in excess of two weeks’ pay for an ordinary laborer, this note features the portrait of Commodore Stephen Decatur Jr., brilliant naval war hero of both Barbary Wars and the War of 1812. As these notes were part of the first issue of notes backed by silver coin, the reverse has the word “silver” spelled out prominently, and the choice of black ink is unique to the early issue in this series.

This note features little-remembered [today] Secretary of the Treasury Daniel Manning, appointed by Grover Cleveland in early 1885, and who served only two years before ill-health forced his resignation. His portrait is flanked by allegorical representations of Agriculture and Industry. Persevering well into the early 20th century, this artistic note was issued with multiple evolutions of the Treasury’s seal, in light red, brown, red and blue; in eight signature combinations; and with and without the doubled blue X overprint seen here.

This is the last design and signature combination issue in the $50 Silver Certificates series and carries the likeness Edward Everett, Congressman, Senator, Governor and 20th Secretary of State. The open design on the back allows the numerous red and blue silk fibers imbedded in the paper to show prominently. At the end of World War I, this was comparable to $750 in current dollars.

Titled as Treasury Notes, and referred to as “Coin Notes,” due to that aspect of their redeemability, these notes were authorized in the July 14, 1890 Legal Tender Act and instructed the Treasury to issue notes exchangeable for and backed by coin without specifying it as gold or silver. Featuring the portrait of Edwin McMasters Stanton, Abraham Lincoln’s second Secretary of War and Andrew Johnson’s first. It was Johnson’s eventual efforts to dismiss Stanton that led to his impeachment. Notice the large brown spiked seal, replaced by a significantly smaller version in later issues. Large block numerals and extensive engraving dominate the back of the note and provided some – but not conclusive – protection against counterfeiting.

Titled as Treasury Notes, and referred to as “Coin Notes,” due to that aspect of their redeemability, these notes were authorized in the July 14, 1890 Legal Tender Act and instructed the Treasury to issue notes exchangeable for and backed by coin without specifying it as gold or silver. Featuring the portrait of Edwin McMasters Stanton, Abraham Lincoln’s second Secretary of War and Andrew Johnson’s first. It was Johnson’s eventual efforts to dismiss Stanton that led to his impeachment. Notice the large brown spiked seal, replaced by a significantly smaller version in later issues. Large block numerals and extensive engraving dominate the back of the note and provided some – but not conclusive – protection against counterfeiting.

Dated just one year later, the backs of the Coin Notes were dramatically redesigned in 1890-91, eliminating the large block style denominations and creating large open areas, framed in and decorated by elegant scrollwork and lathed elements. Issued during the “Art Nouveau” period, they were much in keeping with the European style.

A full 25 years after the end of the Civil War, its heroes were still being commemorated. In this case, General James Birdseye McPherson is lauded. McPherson was a Union general well regarded by commanders Grant and Sherman, but best remembered for his death at the Battle of Atlanta. He was the second highest ranking Union officer lost during the war. Large and ornate block letters and intricate guilloches dominate the note’s back.

While the faces of the Coin Notes were left virtually unchanged, save altering the date, the reverses of the Coin Notes were dramatically redesigned in 1891, eliminating the large block style denominations, creating large open areas, framed in and decorated by elegant scrollwork and lathed elements. Issued during the “Art Nouveau” period, they were much in keeping with the European style.

The face of this note includes a portrait of General George Henry Thomas, now a little-remembered Union general, but presumably remembered by his commanding officer for a good portion of the Civil War. The facsimile signature of William S. Rosecrans appears as Register of the Treasury at the time these notes were designed and issued. The back of the note features a large block style “FIVE,” which is intricately engraved and surrounded by intricate guilloches and engravings.
This is an example of the later issue of these notes, whose new reverse features the larger open areas and elaborate Art Nouveau-style back of the 1891 Coin Note issues.

The face of this note includes a portrait of General George Henry Thomas, now a little-remembered Union general, but presumably remembered by his commanding officer for a good portion of the Civil War. The facsimile signature of William S. Rosecrans appears as Register of the Treasury at the time these notes were designed and issued. The back of the note features a large block style “FIVE,” which is intricately engraved and surrounded by intricate guilloches and engravings.

The face of this note features a portrait of Philip Henry Sheridan, a lifelong soldier who, among other achievements, rose in six months from Captain to Major General during the Civil War, replaced William Tecumseh Sherman as Commander of the Army in 1884 and was appointed General of the Army by Grover Cleveland in the last year of his life, 1888. As do all Coin Notes, the 1890 version of this note carries a fully engraved, complex design on its reverse, including the denomination, “TEN” spelled out in large block-style letters.
The signatures on this last of the $10 Coin Notes place its issuance at the end of the 19th century. It displays the intricately-designed but more modern open back design of the later Coin Notes.

The face of this beautifully engraved note departs from the military personages on the lower denominations in the series, featuring the portrait of John Marshall, Secretary of State and Fourth Chief Justice of the United States. The back follows the style of this note series, with the word “twenty” spelled out.
The updated back of this later note follows in the same fashion as the other notes in this series, with an open and more floral design reminiscent of the Art Nouveau period.

As a result of the passage of the National Bank Act in 1863, the US government allowed individual banks to apply for a federal charter, which when granted allowed the banks the privilege of issuing their own bank notes, backed by United States bonds held in safekeeping by the government. The notes were first printed by independent contractors and later the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, and they included the bank’s name and the signatures of the bank’s officers, as well as the relevant printed Treasury signatures. During the National Bank Note era, 14,348 charters were assigned and roughly 14,000 different banks would issue notes, before the May 31, 1935 end. This $1 example from the Union National Bank of New York City, bearing the first Colby Spinner pair of signatures, was likely issued shortly after the bank’s July 1, 1865 charter. Printed by American Bank Note, it features a vignette entitled “Concordia,” symbolized by two allegorical figures shaking hands at an altar as a symbol of peace.

The reverse of the first charter $1 denominated National Bank Notes feature a vignette titled “Landing of the Pilgrims,” depicting the pilgrims battling their way onto Plymouth Rock. The bi-colored reverses of the first charter notes and incorporated reverse vignettes are some of the finest work in US currency.

Bearing the bright red overprinted number “376,” signifying its having been the 376th bank charter approved by Congress for note issuance, this is an example of a unique design element in federal currency – the use of the denomination itself, rotated 90 degrees and used as the dominant graphic element. The note was issued by the Central National Bank in New York City, which would last into the early 20th century before being absorbed by the National Citizens Bank. The back of the note features Sir Walter Raleigh in 1585 England presenting New World corn and smoking tobacco. Because $2 National Bank Notes were usually printed as the bottom note on a sheet of three singles and a deuce, these so-called “Lazy Deuces” tend to be significantly rarer than their counterparts.

This local issuer, the Central National Bank of the City of New York, was chartered by Congress for issuance in 1864, but the “Series 1875” overprint at the side of the charter number “376” confirm its later date of issue. The vignette at the left is of Christopher Columbus sighting land in the New World; the vignette at right features a native Indian princess being presented to allegorical figures representative of the Old World, and the central vignette on the reverse shows the landing of Columbus in America. This is from a well-capitalized and early, prolific issuer of National Bank notes, and yet is still scarce.

From the first 20-year charter period of this New York, NY, organization’s life as a National Bank, this bill provides a history lesson in the hand, connecting Benjamin Franklin performing his famed electrical experiments with kite and key to heaven-bound allegorical Liberty soaring on an eagle while clutching lightning in her hand. Imaged on the back, from the painting by William Henry Powell commissioned by Congress for the Capitol is an engraving of Hernando de Soto’s 1541 discovery of the Mississippi River. Placed in the rotunda in 1855, the painting was a timely and visible metaphor for the ambitions of a still young, expansive nation.

From an early bank in central Massachusetts, the left vignette features the April 19, 1775 outbreak of military hostilities in the Revolutionary War - the Battle of Lexington. At right, allegorical Columbia with an early flag fronts a group of citizenry. While early charter period product was handled by outside contractors, by these 1875 issues, the Bureau of Engraving and Printing had been created to handle the nation’s currency needs, indicated by the small lettering at the upper right of the face. The reverse features a large format vignette drawn from the John Chapman painting of the 1614 baptism of Pocahontas, which hangs in the Rotunda of the US Capitol.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: As their first 20-year charter periods came to an end, banks applied for their charters to be extended, and new plates with new designs were prepared. Thus began the era of National Bank Notes known as “brown backs,” displaying their charter numbers in teal prominently overprinted over large intricate brown guilloches. This National Bank of Commerce $5 note bears its charter renewal date of January 14, 1885, and the portrait of the [at the time] recently assassinated James A. Garfield. While all the other denominations of the brown backs continued to use the designs of the 1865 and 1875 series, the assassination of Garfield, after seven months in office in 1881, led to his portrait replacing the earlier 1865/1875 designs on the fives. The National Bank of Commerce was the successor bank to the April 1839 created Bank of Commerce, and would come to be controlled by famed J. Pierpont Morgan, whose signature this note bears, renamed Morgan Guaranty and Trust in 1959, and ultimately absorbed into what we know currently as JP Morgan Chase.

The backs of the “brown backs” were relatively standard; they carried each bank’s unique charter number [in this case 1394] prominently overprinted in teal on the brown engraving; the backs also featured the relevant state seal at left and an eagle at the right. The highly visible charter numbers and the large design elements containing the denomination, called “counters,” made sorting the notes of the thousands of different issuing banks easier.

Printed in Washington, DC, these notes were sent to the National Bank of Commerce in New York City for the addition of signatures by its officers before they technically became money and could be issued over the institution’s counters. These notes continued the Benjamin Franklin [left] and Liberty astride an eagle [right] motifs of the 1865 and 1875 series. The National Bank of Commerce was the successor bank to the April 1839 created Bank of Commerce, and would come to be controlled by famed J. Pierpont Morgan, renamed Morgan Guaranty and Trust in 1959, and ultimately absorbed into what we know currently as JP Morgan Chase.

General George Washington’s 1776 crossing of the Delaware is memorialized on the left of this early Pittsburgh bank, and his appeal at prayer at right. Issuance of high denomination notes tended to be less popular amongst smaller banks, but large establishments such as this one – the Exchange National Bank – had use for them. At the time of its 1931 failure in the Depression, this bank had $742,980 in aggregate face value in circulation. Today 25 to 50 notes are estimated to remain.

Representing a significant sum of money [over $2,500 in current dollars], this was the largest denomination issued in the brown back series. Only 2,486 of these notes were issued by the Rock Island Bank, and given its 1915 liquidation, this is a miracle of survival. On the left is an image of Commander Oliver Hazard Perry, the “Hero of Lake Erie,” on his way from his disabled flagship, the Lawrence, to the Niagara, with which he would win the battle. At right an allegorical Liberty holds a fasces, a symbol of power and strength dating back to Etruscan civilization. Here it bears a label “The Union,” symbolizing the strength of many bound together in common cause.

After the Panic of 1907, Congress passed the Aldrich-Vreeland Act of 1908, one of the provisos of which was the expansion of suitable securities which could be pledged to secure the National Banks’ outstanding currency issues. This note, while bearing the Treasury signatures of Judson Lyons and Ellis Roberts, who served together from 1898 to 1905, bears modifications to the security language at upper center “or other Securities.” In order to more readily distinguish the newer notes with their slightly differing status, seal, serial and charter number, colors were changed to blue from brown, and new backs were designed, reverting to the traditional green ink, and bearing the dates 1882-1908. Beginning in 1916, the backs of notes still issuing second charter notes were again re-designed, to bear the denomination of the note spelled out – in the case of this Peoples National Bank of Hoosick Falls note, “Five Dollars.” As such, these notes are referred to as “value backs,” and as a class of note are quite scarce.

In 1902, the third charter period began, and thus the Bureau of Engraving and Printing prepared an entirely new set of designs for National Currency. The 23rd President, Benjamin Harrison, had passed away the previous year, and was honored with placement on the new currency. The reverse features the by then familiar but popular vignette of the landing of the Pilgrims. First issued with red seals, the legal language on these notes was affected by passage of the Aldrich-Vreeland Act of 1908, one of the provisos of which was the expansion of suitable securities which could be pledged to secure the National Banks’ outstanding currency issues. The notes security language was modified to include “or other Securities,” and the seal, serial and charter number colors were changed to blue. The dates 1902-1908 were added to the backs, and these notes are classed as “1902 date backs.” When the legislation expired in 1915, the dates were removed, and these notes, including this Chase National example, are called “plain backs.”

In 1902, the third charter period began, and thus the Bureau of Engraving and Printing prepared an entirely new set of designs for National Currency. The 23rd President, Benjamin Harrison, had passed away the previous year, and was honored with placement on the new currency. The reverse features the by then familiar but popular vignette of the landing of the Pilgrims. First issued with red seals, the legal language on these notes was affected by passage of the Aldrich-Vreeland Act of 1908, one of the provisos of which was the expansion of suitable securities which could be pledged to secure the National Banks’ outstanding currency issues. The notes security language was modified to include “or other Securities,” and the seal, serial and charter number colors were changed to blue. The dates 1902-1908 were added to the backs, and these notes are classed as “1902 date backs.” When the legislation expired in 1915, the dates were removed, and these notes, including this Chase National example, are called “plain backs.”

Bearing the portrait of at-the-time recently assassinated William McKinley, the first issue of the third charter period, which began in 1902, bore red seals, charter numbers and serial numbers. Because later issues with blue seals had less favorable redemption privileges, red seals began to disappear rapidly from circulation and are relatively rare today. Because the issuing bank, The Greenwich National Bank of Greenwich, Connecticut, was a small, short-lived institution, this is a rare note. Its reverse bears an allegory with shield and fasces, flanked by oceanic strength.

The “8243” on the face of this note is in reference to the issuing bank, The Greenwich National Bank, having been granted the 8,243rd charter [in 1906] under the National Bank Act. Every bank so chartered received a number which, from the mid-1870s, was included on every note. At the time of its inception, this bank was chartered with $50,000 in capital, and banks could be chartered with as little as $25,000 under the legislation. This allowed even small communities all over the nation to start their own “hometown banks,” allowing the populace not only the convenience and safety of a depository institution, but also allowed local financing to flourish. While a short lived and therefore rare bank, it issued 48,136 notes before closing its doors in 1923. A handful of these notes remain today. The blue seal, serial and charter numbers, along with a back that features a vignette of an allegory and the Capitol only, identify this as a so-called “plain back.”

As charter number 13044 on A.P. Giannini’s famous Bank of Italy in San Francisco, would suggest, this institution was approved late [February of 1927] in the National Banking era. A later portrait of John Sherman – Congressman, Senator, Secretary of State, Secretary of the Treasury and author of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act – appears at left. On the reverse, a locomotive pulling a train at speed is featured amongst allegories.

A delightful example of hometown banking, the signers of this Terre Haute bank note are evidently related, as the Cashier is signing as “S.C. McKeen” and the President of the bank is “W.R. McKeen.” It then perhaps comes as no surprise that the bank is named The McKeen National Bank of Terre Haute. The $100 denomination is the highest in this next-to-last series of the third charter period, called “date backs” because the Aldrich-Vreeland Act resulted in a change to the acceptable forms of securities banks could pledge. This was signified to the public by the addition of the relevant dates, 1902-1908, on the notes’ reverses.

The creation of the Federal Reserve System in 1913 called for two new classes of currency. One was the “Federal Reserve Note,” precursor to the notes universally circulating as currency today. These notes, while issued by the 12 district banks, are general obligations of the Federal Reserve System. Also authorized were Federal Reserve Bank Notes, legal obligations of the individual banks. While the Act was passed in 1913, only fives, tens and twenties were authorized at the time, and the first issue of Federal Reserve Bank Notes did not come until 1915. Ones, like this example, were not issued until 1918. This St. Louis district issue features George Washington at left and numerous combinations of the letter “H” and the number “8” corresponding to St. Louis’ status as the eighth of the 12 banks in the system. The reverse has a dramatic spread-wing eagle with the nation’s flag in his talons.

This $2 Federal Reserve Bank Note denomination was also authorized by the later Act of April, 1918, and carries the series of 1918 designation below the Treasury seal at right. This note was printed by the Bureau of Engraving and Printing for issue by the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank [3rd district] and features the portrait of President Thomas Jefferson at left.

As these notes bear the engraved of the relevant Treasury officials and the Cashier and Governor of the individual Federal Reserve Bank, numerous different combinations abound for this series. This $5 bill, issued by the 10th Federal Reserve district, is from Kansas City and bears the engraved local signatures of Arch W. Anderson as Cashier Jo Zach Miller, Jr. as Governor.

From the earlier 1915 dated series, indicated by the small legend above the upper right serial number, this Federal Reserve Bank Note is from the 11th Federal Reserve district of Dallas, Texas. Featuring the portrait of President Andrew Jackson, the Cashier’s and Governor’s signatures were applied after the notes were printed in a separate operation.

Featuring Grover Cleveland at left, the only US President to serve two non-consecutive terms – the 22nd [1885-89], and 24th [1893-97] – this note was designed and memorialized him less than a decade after his death. It was issued by the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank, the 6th district.

The creation of the Federal Reserve System in 1913 called for two new classes of currency. One was the “Federal Reserve Note,” precursor to the notes universally circulating as currency today. These notes, while issued by the 12 district banks, are general obligations of the Federal Reserve System. Also authorized were Federal Reserve Bank Notes, legal obligations of the individual banks. While the Act was passed in 1913, only fives, tens and twenties were authorized at the time, and the first issue of Federal Reserve Bank Notes did not come until 1915. Ones, like this example, were not issued until 1918. This Cleveland district issue features George Washington at left and numerous combinations of the letter “D” and the number “4” corresponding to Cleveland’s status as the fourth of the 12 banks in the system. The reverse has a dramatic spread-wing eagle with the nation’s flag in his talons.

The creation of the Federal Reserve System in 1913 called for two new classes of currency. One was the “Federal Reserve Note,” precursor to the notes universally circulating as currency today. These notes, while issued by the 12 district banks, are general obligations of the Federal Reserve System. Also authorized were Federal Reserve Bank Notes, legal obligations of the individual banks. The initial issues of the Federal Reserve Notes bore red Treasury seals and serial numbers, later converted to blue. This lowest denomination in the series is from the New York Federal Reserve district, and while printed in Washington, would have passed through the Federal Reserve Bank a few blocks from Wall Street and would have eventually been paid out to a member bank for distribution to the general public.

The backs of all of the Federal Reserve Notes share designs with their brethren, the Federal Reserve Bank Notes authorized by the same Act. However, the words “National Currency” and “Bank” have been removed. This note has a design similar to the 1918 Federal Reserve Bank Note five, featuring the vignette of Columbus sighting land at the left and the landing of the Pilgrims” at the right.

The back design reflects the importance of the country’s agrarian and industrial activities to its future prosperity. It shows farmers harvesting wheat at the left and a factory operating at full capacity at the right.

A later blue seal issue from the New York district, featuring a portrait of President Andrew Jackson, the White/Mellon signature combinations place this as issued shortly before the 1928 conversion to the small size currency we use today. While featured prominently on our nation’s currency, Jackson famously opposed the central bank of his day, the Second Bank of the United States. The vignette is from original artwork painted in 1824 by Thomas Sully.

This red seal note from the Philadelphia Federal Reserve features Grover Cleveland at left, the only US President to serve two non-consecutive terms – the 22nd [1885-89] and 24th [1893-97]. These notes were designed less than a decade after his 1908 death.

The imagery on the reverse of this note conveys the importance of land, sea and air transportation to the nation. The left vignette features a bi-plane, a steam locomotive pulling a train and a period automobile. At right a large passenger ship steams out of New York harbor, paced by a tug or pilot, with the Statue of Liberty and the city’s skyline in the distance. The back of this note is similar in design to the 1915 and 1918 issues of the Federal Reserve Bank Notes.

Featuring the portrait of General Ulysses S. Grant, and the Treasury signatures of John Burke and William C. McAdoo, this Richmond district red seal began circulating right around the time of the completion of the Panama Canal, viewed as a significant international economic and engineering triumph by the country at the time. The back of this note features the central allegory, titled “Panama,” flanked by ships. The “1-A” in the seal at left indicates this was a later blue seal of the $50 denomination from the Boston Federal Reserve district.

Featuring the portrait of General Ulysses S. Grant, and the Treasury signatures of John Burke and William C. McAdoo, this Richmond district red seal began circulating right around the time of the completion of the Panama Canal, viewed as a significant international economic and engineering triumph by the country at the time. The back of this note features the central allegory, titled “Panama,” flanked by ships. The “1-A” in the seal at left indicates this was a later blue seal of the $50 denomination from the Boston Federal Reserve district.

The series 1914 red seal $100 dollar notes feature a vignette of Benjamin Franklin in profile, inspired [it would appear] by one of the Jean Antoine Houdon works made while Franklin resided in Paris. This note arguably had purchasing power in its day of at least 20 times its counterpart today.

The back of the 1914 $100 Federal Reserve Note shows a scene of allegorical figures done in an unusual form for US currency, in tribute to classic Greek style. Intended to portray, from left, Labor, Plenty, America, Peace and Commerce, America is central and the most prominent, flanked by Plenty and Peace. Labor, manifested by the harvesting farmer is at left, and commerce is symbolized by the use of the god Mercury, with winged sandals, hat and caduceus.

NoteInfo.NoteType: National Gold Bank Note of California
NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: After the California Gold Rush, the population of California continued to grow, as did commerce. As the region’s principal medium of exchange was gold, the banks spent much of their day counting gold coin, which was heavy and inconvenient. As a result, in 1870, Congress authorized the creation of 10 National Gold Banks, which were allowed to issue currency redeemable in gold coin. This example is drawn on the First National Gold Bank of San Francisco. These notes were issued in the early 1870s and are quite rare, as by 1885 all of the chartered Gold Banks had ceased issuance, either due to liquidation or conversion. This is the only group of National Bank Notes denominated in gold.

NoteInfo.NoteType: National Gold Bank Note of California
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: Printed on a unique yellow-tinted paper, the fronts of these notes utilized the same design elements as the $5 National Bank Notes of the First Charter Period, featuring the vignette of Columbus sighting land at the left, and a native Indian princess being presented to the Old World at right. However, reverses of these notes feature a distinctive departure – a large vignette of the American gold coins of the time, which includes at least one example of each denomination, from $1 to the “Double Eagle,” or $20 piece.

Nine different series of Gold Certificates were issued, beginning with the Act of March 1863, but only four really saw public circulation. This $20 note is from the first of those, the fourth issue, and features the portrait of President James A. Garfield, assassinated very shortly before this issue was designed. The orange, or “gold,” back depicts an eagle carrying a lightning bolt and commemorates completion of the first transatlantic cable, in 1858. Gold Notes, commonly encountered in circulation in their heyday, are comparatively rare today because of President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s 1933 call for the American public to turn in their gold coin and currency denominated in gold. The surrendered notes were destroyed.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Museum of American Finance
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: Nine different series of Gold Certificates were issued, beginning with the Act of March 1863, but only four really saw public circulation. This $20 note is from the first of those, the fourth issue, and features the portrait of President James A. Garfield, assassinated very shortly before this issue was designed. The orange, or “gold,” back depicts an eagle carrying a lightning bolt and commemorates completion of the first transatlantic cable, in 1858. Gold Notes, commonly encountered in circulation in their heyday, are comparatively rare today because of President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s 1933 call for the American public to turn in their gold coin and currency denominated in gold. The surrendered notes were destroyed.

The first two issues of the 1905 $20 gold certificate featured a vivid yellow underprint, bright red seals and red serial numbers, surrounded by a richly ornate border. Called the “Technicolor Note” because of the extensive use of color, later designs were modified to allow the note faces to be produced with only two inks, black and yellow/orange. This is arguably one of the most beautiful pieces of US currency.

The back of the $20 Gold Certificate is orange in color, connoting gold, and features elaborate engraving work and the very pronounced words “Gold Certificate.” These notes were exchangeable by law until 1933 for gold coins, and were preferred by “hard money” types.

This early $50 Gold Certificate features the portrait of a by-now comparatively obscure pre-Civil War politician, Silas Wright. However, during his service as a Congressman [1827-1829], Senator [1833-1844] and Governor of New York [1845-1846], he played prominent roles in significant political debates and several of the nation’s formative decisions. Issued early in the 20th century and equivalent to well in excess of $1,000 in purchasing power today, the earlier issues in this series were countersigned and payable in New York City, the later language on this note adopted beginning with the Blanche Bruce and Albert Wyman signed notes. Note the use of color and the underprinted word “gold” in the background.

This is the last issue of the large size Gold Certificates in the $50 denomination, and the portrait of Ulysses S. Grant, familiarly associated with $50 bill, is employed. When superseded by the 1928 conversion to small size currency, most of the facial design elements would continue, but the orange “gold backs” would disappear.
The back of this note features beautiful scrollwork and imagery, in an Art Nouveau design.

This note features the fitting portrait of Senator Thomas Hart Benton of Missouri, nicknamed “Old Bullion” for his staunch support of “hard money,” i.e., gold and silver specie. This design, unlike the others in the 1882 series, remained unchanged though 14 signature combinations before the 1928 conversion to small size design.

The back of this uncommon note shows the fighting American eagle in gold color, as well as a guilloche at left with the Roman numeral style “C,” for 100. Today, people still refer to $100 bills as “C-Notes.”

These notes were not printed with public use intended. Rather, as the face and blank backs suggest, they were to be used for payments involving the Federal Reserve, and while payable in gold, were not actually secured by gold on hand. The examples which are in the hands of the public literally fell into their hands. During a December 1935 fire at the Old Post Office in Washington, DC, a group of items, included these cancelled notes, were thrown through the windows in an effort to save them. Passersby picked them up, and many bear the signs of fire, smoke and water damage.

The smallest denomination and smallest format piece of US currency, these notes were issued at a time when the postal rate for a letter was three cents. The wording on the reverse promises in part: “This note is exchangeable for United States Notes by Assistant Treasurers and designated depositaries of the United States in sums not less than three dollars.” In other words, the government was willing to redeem these notes, but not for specie, and not one at a time.

Even notes of such small denominations were subject to counterfeiting, and the second issues of fractional currency were overprinted with a carefully developed bronze metallic overprint intended to foil efforts to copy the notes. The overprint on the front of the notes took the form of a bold large oval, circling the portrait, and the denomination numeral in outline form on the reverse. Contemporary reports suggest that good imitations of the second issue, including the bronzing, began appearing within a week of the notes’ release.

The placement of Spencer M. Clark, First Superintendent of the National Currency Bureau [now known as the Bureau of Engraving and Printing], created significant controversy at the time of issue, and led directly to swift legislation that remains in place today, to the effect that no living person shall be featured on the nation’s currency.

Bearing an image of identical size and color of the engraved 10 cent postage stamp of the day, these notes were produced with and without perforations, by contract with both the American and National Bank Note Companies. This note, perforated and with the monogram on the reverse of “ABC,” was the product of both National Bank Note [the front] and American Bank Note [reverse]. This first issue was the only issue labeled “Postage Currency.”

When it was discovered that perforating the sheets of notes made them significantly more likely to tear early in circulation, it was decided to cut them apart manually. Because the Civil War had made available men scarce, the government’s first female employees were hired to cut the notes apart and prepare them for distribution to the public. This note, bearing no reverse monogram, was printed entirely by the National Bank Note Company. This first issue was the only issue labeled “Postage Currency.”
The last [5th] issue of fractional currency arrived in only three denominations: 10, 25 and 50 cents. William Meredith, featured here, was Secretary of the Treasury from 1849 to 1850.
The only 15 cent denomination issued and featuring “Columbia,” this note represented a denomination never issued in coin form.

In order that the public might more easily identify their value, the first fractional notes introduced bore the images of the stamps being used in commerce as substitute for the scarce coin which had disappeared. In this case, the engraved image is of five of the brown five cent stamps in use at the time, slightly overlapping.
William P. Fessenden, a Congressman, Senator and President Lincoln’s second of three Secretaries of the Treasury, appears on this elegantly designed note.

Aside from the change in denominations, the front designs of the second issue are identical. All four denominations feature the oval portrait of George Washington, with maritime, commerce and railroad themes at the bottom of the design. The reverses are also similar, but printed in different colors. The back of this 50 cent note was printed in a brilliant orange with a bronze “50” overprint in bronze ink.

Francis E. Spinner was an upstate New York banker and politician appointed by Abraham Lincoln in March of 1861 to serve as Treasurer. He oversaw the Treasury during the pivotal Civil War years, serving under Presidents Johnson and Grant as well, until resigning in 1875. His distinctive signature at the lower right graces many of the early issues of US currency.

After passage by Congress of legislation forbidding the portrait of living persons appearing on US currency, inspired by the vignette of Spencer Clark appearing on the five cent 3rd issue notes, all living persons were removed from the currency, including Treasurer Francis Spinner. The note design was left intact, and an allegorical vignette of seated Justice replaced the portrait.
