Released beginning in 1869, the 4th issue 50 cent notes feature a somber, somewhat younger-looking portrait of Lincoln than we typically see. Despite the comparatively low face value of the smaller notes, in addition to the care taken in producing high-quality engraved face and reverse plates, the notes were printed on high-quality watermarked paper imbedded with pink silk fibers.

Featuring Lincoln’s second Secretary of War, Edwom Stanton, in the identical portrait seen on late Coin Notes of 1890 and 1891, these notes were the second variety of 50 cent notes released under the 4th issue.

Featured on the last of three 4th issue 50 cent notes, Samuel Dexter served 13 months in John Adams’ cabinet positions, five as the nation’s 3rd Secretary of the Treasury and eight as the 4th Secretary of War.

The last 50 cent fractional note, printed for two years [1874-1876], this piece bears the portrait of William Harris Crawford, Secretary of the Treasury [1815-16], Secretary of War [1816-1825] and unsuccessful candidate for President in 1824, ultimately losing to John Quincy Adams.

In 1928, the government finally implemented a decision which had been discussed since World War I. In the long term, reducing the size of the country’s large bank notes offered significant savings, particularly in the categories of the highly-specialized [and expensive] Crane paper, as well as the specialized printing inks in use. In the short term, however, the switch from large size notes to small size notes would require new designs, new plates and new presses. And, while today we utilize only one form of note, the Federal Reserve Note, conversion in the 1928-1929 period would see Silver Certificates, Gold Certificates, National Bank Notes, Federal Reserve Bank Notes and Federal Reserve Notes replaced. After years of planning, the first small size notes appeared on January 10, 1929. The large size notes they supplanted continued to circulate as legal tender and remain redeemable at face today. This note replaced the 1923 dated large size legal tender note, and while dated 1928, was actually printed in 1933; the majority of the print run was held in storage until the Recession of 1948-9 and released over a period of months in Puerto Rico only, to save on counting costs. Series 1928 was the only small size $1 Legal Tender Note issued.

Until the 1976 issuance of $2 Federal Reserve Notes with a re-designed reverse, the only $2 bills printed in small size were United States Notes, bearing red seals. The last series date was 1963A, and on August 10, 1966, the Treasury announced that it would cease printing all Legal Tender Notes. The reverse of these notes features Monticello, home of Thomas Jefferson. Notice that these notes do not carry the “In God We Trust” motto; this was added to the 1966 series.

This note, whose design looks familiar to us today despite the red seals and serial numbers, replaced the large size “Woodchopper” note, which is in this exhibit (1869 $5 Legal Tender Note), and whose design had been in use essentially unchanged since 1869. In an effort to ready the public for not only the design changes, but also the shift in paper dimensions, the Treasury, the Federal Reserve System and the nation’s banks engaged in an extensive campaign to acquaint people with the new currency, including giving out advertising in card form explaining that the card was sized in the dimensions of the new currency.

The original February 1862 legislation creating Legal Tender Notes reflected the nation’s distrust of fiat currency, and despite the urgency of the Civil War, only $150 million in issuance was authorized. This was doubled to $300 million in July of 1862 and ultimately increased to $346,681,016 by the Act of May 3, 1878, where it remained. When on August 10, 1966 the Treasury made the decision to stop printing Legal Tender Notes, the series 1966 and series 1966A $100 denominations were stockpiled to meet the requirements of law without needing to continue printing and issuing them to the public. In 1993, the Legal Tender Act was repealed, and the notes held in storage were subsequently destroyed.

As originally required by law, silver certificates were intended to be backed by physically coined silver held by the Treasury, and payable to the holder upon demand. As coining silver was expensive, and storing bagged coin was unwieldy, the wording on the notes was altered, beginning with the 1934 Series including this note. The new obligation promised payment in silver, but not necessarily in silver coin. On June 24th, 1968, Congress legislated discontinuance of the practice of paying out silver bullion, although silver certificates, like all Federal Currency, remain redeemable and have legal tender status.

Just as all large size Treasury and Federal Reserve System currency was converted to small size, the government had to make arrangements for the National Banks who were issuing their own notes, printed in Washington and secured by US bonds the banks had purchased. The solution, as seen here, was to utilize the new small bank note size and portraiture, building standard plates which allowed the addition, during two final printings, of 1] the name of the institution, its charter number [printed twice] in black letters and numbers and the engraved signatures of the cashier and president, and 2] the serial number and Treasury seal in brown. In a later variant, the charter would be added a third and fourth time in brown. At the time of the 1929 conversion, over 6,000 banks were still active and issuing large size National Bank Notes, and in the 1929 to 1935 period, another 900 new ones would be chartered.

While all but the $1 and $2 small size Federal Reserve Notes have gone through a re-design in the last quarter century to modernize them and, in particular, enhance their anti-counterfeiting capabilities, today’s Federal Reserve Notes maintain the same familiar portraits, green seals and denominations set in 1928 when the transition to small size was made. Interestingly, the language on this first issue from Boston dated 1928 states, “Redeemable in Gold Coin on Demand at the United States Treasury, or in Gold or Lawful Money at any Federal Reserve Bank.” Beginning with the 1934 series, this language was altered to “This Note is Legal Tender for all Debts, Public and Private, and is Redeemable in Lawful Money at the United States Treasury, or any Federal Reserve Bank,” reflecting the June 5, 1933 decision to take the United States off the Gold Standard. Beginning with the series of 1963, and as of today, it reads, “This Note is Legal Tender for all Debts, Public and Private.”

Beginning with the 1934 series, as can be seen here, the redemption language on Federal Reserve Notes was substantially altered, to read “This Note is Legal Tender for all Debts, Public and Private, and is Redeemable in Lawful Money at the United States Treasury, or any Federal Reserve Bank,” reflecting the June 5, 1933 decision to take the United States off the Gold Standard. Beginning with the series of 1963, and as of today, it reads, “This Note is Legal Tender for all Debts, Public and Private.”

The changeover to small size currency included Gold Certificates. The bright orange backs of the large size issues were replaced by conventional green backs, but gold was still symbolized by the Treasury seals and serial numbers printed in a yellow/orange. This is the $10 denomination, and like all these issues was short lived, being decoupled from convertibility to gold by President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s 1933 call for the American public to turn in their gold coin, as well as currency denominated in gold.

The changeover to small size currency included Gold Certificates. The bright orange backs of the large size issues were replaced by conventional green backs, but gold was still symbolized by the Treasury seals and serial numbers printed in a yellow/orange. This is the $20 issue, and like all these issues was short lived, being decoupled from convertibility to gold by President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s 1933 call for the American public to turn in their gold coin, as well as currency denominated in gold.

The changeover to small size currency included Gold Certificates. The bright orange backs of the large size issues were replaced by conventional green backs, but gold was still symbolized by the Treasury seals and serial numbers printed in a yellow/orange. This is the $50 issue, and like all these issues was short lived, being decoupled from convertibility to gold by President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s 1933 call for the American public to turn in their gold coin and currency denominated in gold. The reverse of this note looks very similar to the modern $50 bill, except it does not have the words “In God We Trust.”

The changeover to small size currency included Gold Certificates. The bright orange backs of the large size issues were replaced by conventional green backs, but gold was still symbolized by the Treasury seals and serial numbers printed in a yellow/orange. This is the $100 issue, and like all these issues was short lived, being decoupled from convertibility to gold by President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s 1933 call for the American public to turn in their gold coin, as well as currency denominated in gold.

This note represented a considerable amount of money when it was issued in 1928. Notably, it was convertible at the time into 25 $20 gold pieces. Today those 25 coins would contain bullion value in gold of $25,000. As was the case for all Gold Certificates, this note was decoupled from conversion to gold, but as with all United States currency, it still legal tender today.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: This note has been loaned to the Museum, courtesy of the Federal Reserve Bank. It is a $100,000 bill that was never issued for use by individuals. These were used by the federal government in balance of payments to other governments, so that they didn’t have to move around big gold bars. Notice that the serial number is all zeroes, and that the front includes the word “Specimen.” This means that this was not a bank note that would ever have actually been issued, but rather an example of a bank note that was in use.

This is a $500 bill issued in 1928. As with all of the 1928 Federal Reserve Notes issued in all denominations, these notes carried the promise “Redeemable in Gold Coin on Demand at the United States Treasury, or in Gold or Lawful Money at any Federal Reserve Bank.” The 1934 series, while similar in appearance overall, had an important change in the language, to “This Note is Legal Tender for all Debts, Public and Private, and is Redeemable in Lawful Money at the United States Treasury, or any Federal Reserve Bank,” reflecting the June 5, 1933 decision to take the United States off the Gold Standard. These bills remain legal tender today, although they command a premium over their face value in the collector’s marketplace.

This is the reverse of the 1934 New York Federal Reserve $500 bill, issued shortly after the onset of the Great Depression and the United States’ shift off the Gold Standard. The last series of this denomination, the 1934-C series, was printed in the late 1940s and into the 1950s. It bears the signatures of W.A. Julian and John Snyder.

During the shift from large size to small size currency, Grover Cleveland’s portrait on the large size Federal Reserve $20 note was replaced by Andrew Jackson’s, but in turn replaced Hamilton’s on the $1,000 bill. This, the 1934 series issue of the $1,000 Federal Reserve Note, remains legal tender, and could be redeemed at its place of issue, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, a few short blocks from Wall Street. The language in the fine print at upper left, “This Note is Legal Tender for all Debts, Public and Private, and is Redeemable in Lawful Money at the United States Treasury, or any Federal Reserve Bank,” reflects the June 5, 1933 decision to take the United States off the Gold Standard.

During the shift from large size to small size currency, Grover Cleveland’s portrait on the large size Federal Reserve $20 note was replaced by Andrew Jackson’s, but in turn replaced Hamilton’s on the $1,000 bill. This, the 1934 series issue of the $1,000 Federal Reserve Note, remains legal tender, and could be redeemed at its place of issue, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, a few short blocks from Wall Street. The language in the fine print at upper left, “This Note is Legal Tender for all Debts, Public and Private, and is Redeemable in Lawful Money at the United States Treasury, or any Federal Reserve Bank,” reflects the June 5, 1933 decision to take the United States off the Gold Standard.

During the shift from large size to small size currency, Grover Cleveland’s portrait on the large size Federal Reserve $20 note was replaced by Andrew Jackson’s, but in turn replaced Hamilton’s on the $1,000 bill. This, the 1934 series issue of the $1,000 Federal Reserve Note, remains legal tender, and could be redeemed at its place of issue, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, a few short blocks from Wall Street. The language in the fine print at upper left, “This Note is Legal Tender for all Debts, Public and Private, and is Redeemable in Lawful Money at the United States Treasury, or any Federal Reserve Bank,” reflects the June 5, 1933 decision to take the United States off the Gold Standard.

NoteInfo.Credit: Collection of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York
Collection of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York
NoteInfo.IndividualNoteInfo: Issued by 11 of the 12 districts [only Philadelphia did not issue], $10,000 small size notes were printed in limited quantities and did not circulate extensively.

From a legislative standpoint, the small size Federal Reserve Bank Notes are a continuation of the large size 1914 - 1918 series, which were obligations not of the Federal Reserve System as a whole [Federal Reserve Notes] but of each individual Federal Reserve Bank as issued the note. And while dated Series of 1929, these notes were actually printed on an emergency basis in 1933 to meet the currency needs during the banking crisis at the beginning of the Great Depression. Unissued sheets printed for use for National Bank Notes were utilized, and each Federal Reserve Bank’s District Letter, name, and the signatures of the officers were overprinted.

From a legislative standpoint, the small size Federal Reserve Bank Notes are a continuation of the large size 1914 - 1918 series, which were obligations not of the Federal Reserve System as a whole [Federal Reserve Notes] but of each individual Federal Reserve Bank as issued the note. And while dated Series of 1929, these notes were actually printed on an emergency basis in 1933 to meet the currency needs during the banking crisis at the beginning of the Great Depression. Unissued sheets printed for use for National Bank Notes were utilized, and each Federal Reserve Bank’s District Letter, name, and the signatures of the officers were overprinted.

After the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, the possibility of the islands, and the currency circulating there, falling into enemy hands led to a decision to issue a special series of currency which was readily distinguishable and could de-monetized if need be with minimal disruption or confusion. One dollar Silver Certificates and $5, $10 and $20 Federal Reserve Notes printed for the San Francisco district were overprinted “Hawaii” on the face and back, and given brown Treasury seals so that they could be readily distinguished. Issuance began June 25, 1942, and ran through October 21, 1944.

Issuance began June 25, 1942, and ran through October 21, 1944.

Issued for use during World War II, these notes were an emergency measure taken out of concern that currency in use by US military personnel operating in North Africa and Sicily might fall into enemy hands. In order to distinguish the notes from conventional US Silver Certificates, they had a yellow Treasury seal in lieu of the standard blue seal. These notes were issued in denominations of $1, $5 and $10.
